title: Diabetes Distress Scale (DDS17)
description: Measures diabetes-related emotional distress across four domains to identify sources of distress and guide targeted interventions for patients with diabetes.

result.name: diabetes_distress_assessment
result.description: Comprehensive diabetes distress assessment with total score and subscale scores

ranges.interpretation: Patients demonstrate good emotional adaptation to diabetes management with minimal distress. Continue current support and monitor periodically for changes in distress levels.
Patients experience moderate diabetes-related distress that may benefit from targeted support and intervention. Consider discussing specific sources of distress and developing coping strategies.

Patients experience significant diabetes-related distress that warrants clinical attention and intervention. This level of distress is associated with poorer glycemic control and self-care behaviors. Recommend referral to diabetes educator, psychologist, or specialized diabetes support services.

emotional_burden.description: Emotional distress related to living with diabetes
emotional_burden.interpretation: High scores indicate significant emotional impact of diabetes on daily life, including feelings of being overwhelmed, discouraged, and the mental energy required for diabetes management.

physician_distress.description: Distress related to healthcare provider relationship
physician_distress.interpretation: High scores suggest dissatisfaction with diabetes care provider, including concerns about physician knowledge, communication, and support for diabetes management.

regimen_distress.description: Distress related to diabetes management regimen
regimen_distress.interpretation: High scores indicate difficulty with diabetes self-care tasks, including blood glucose monitoring, dietary restrictions, and adherence to treatment recommendations.

interpersonal_distress.description: Distress related to family and social support
interpersonal_distress.interpretation: High scores suggest problems with social support, including lack of understanding from family/friends or perceived interference with diabetes management.

clinical_applications: Screening for diabetes-related emotional distress in clinical settings
Identifying specific sources of diabetes distress for targeted intervention
Monitoring response to diabetes distress interventions over time
Research on diabetes distress and its relationship to diabetes outcomes
Quality improvement initiatives in diabetes care programs
Comprehensive diabetes care assessment and care planning
Referral decisions for specialized diabetes support services

scoring_methodology.total_score: Sum all 17 items and divide by 17 to obtain mean item score
scoring_methodology.subscale_scores: Sum items in each subscale and divide by number of items in subscale
scoring_methodology.interpretation_threshold: Mean item score ≥3.0 indicates high distress requiring clinical intervention
scoring_methodology.response_scale: 6-point Likert scale: 1=Not a problem, 2=A slight problem, 3=A moderate problem, 4=Somewhat serious problem, 5=A serious problem, 6=A very serious problem

psychometric_properties.validity: Validated across diverse diabetes populations with established clinical cut points
psychometric_properties.clinical_utility: Demonstrated association with glycemic control, self-efficacy, and diabetes self-care behaviors

references: Polonsky WH, Fisher L, Earles J, et al. Assessing psychosocial distress in diabetes: development of the diabetes distress scale. Diabetes Care. 2005;28(3):626-631. doi: 10.2337/diacare.28.3.626.

Fisher L, Hessler DM, Polonsky WH, Mullan J. When is diabetes distress clinically meaningful?: establishing cut points for the Diabetes Distress Scale. Diabetes Care. 2012;35(2):259-264. doi: 10.2337/dc11-1572.
Fisher L, Glasgow RE, Mullan JT, Skaff MM, Polonsky WH. Development of a brief diabetes distress screening instrument. Ann Fam Med. 2008;6(3):246-252. doi: 10.1370/afm.842.

Hessler D, Fisher L, Polonsky W, et al. Diabetes distress is linked with worsening diabetes management over time in adults with Type 1 diabetes. Diabet Med. 2017;34(9):1228-1234. doi: 10.1111/dme.13381.
formula: DDS17 Total Score = (Sum of all 17 items) / 17; Subscale Scores = (Sum of subscale items) / (Number of items in subscale)
notes: DDS17 assesses diabetes-specific distress, not general psychological distress
Higher scores indicate greater diabetes-related distress
Score ≥3.0 is considered clinically meaningful and warrants intervention
Four subscales help identify specific areas of distress for targeted intervention
Can be used in both Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes populations
Should be administered in clinical settings as part of comprehensive diabetes care
Results should be discussed with patients to develop appropriate support strategies
May be used to monitor response to diabetes distress interventions over time
Consider referral to mental health professionals for scores ≥3.0 with additional clinical concerns

validation.population: Adults with Type 1 or Type 2 diabetes
validation.evidence_basis: Extensively validated instrument with established psychometric properties and clinical cut points
validation.clinical_utility: Widely used tool for diabetes distress assessment with proven clinical and research applications
